git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-deployment refs/changes/11/73211/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: During build preparation this folder will be copied entirely to the **/opt/image-builder** folder. In this document we refer to that folder using variable **IMAGE_BUILDER_ROOT**. config.ini ---------- Config file consists of the following sections: * Default section - Could be names as DEFAULT only. Only one section should be defined, and it should be the first section in the file. This section defines variables which are evaluated and exported as reqular env variables during scripts execution. These variables could be used in subsequent sections (as IMAGE_BUILDER_ROOT does). * Prerequisite sections - Could be named as you want. Any number of sections is allowed. These sections define options which allows to perform various tasks on dependencies, such as validating, renaming, downloading. Dependency options """""""""""""""""" * name - file name for the dependency * url - URL which could be used to download missing dependency file * path - path where the file will be stored * mandatory - identifies the dependency as "must exists or die", allowed values are 'true' and 'false' * skip - skips section, helps when you need to skip a section and do not want to comment many lines :) Allowed values are 'true' and 'false'Files that **MUST** be placed under **$IMAGE_BUILDER_ROOT/libvirt/images** folder are defined in config file with "mandatory = 'true'" option. Files that **MUST** be placed under **$IMAGE_BUILDER_ROOT/share/files** are described in README file under **share/files** subfolder.1. Run **install.sh** to install required prerequisites and configure system. This script will create folder structure, install required packages and configure Samba share required by build script. 2. Run **make build-root** to update build root directory content. 3. Copy prerequisite files to their folders. 4. Run **make test-build-files** to ensure that all files are in place. 5. Run **make** to show available image targets. 6. Run **make <image target>** to build image. 7. Image file should be saved under **$IMAGE_BUILDER_ROOT/libvirt/images** folder.
deleted_lines: During build preparation this folder will be copied entirely to the **/opt/image-builder** folder. We refer to that folder using variable **BUILD_ROOT**.The following ISO files **MUST** be placed under **$BUILD_ROOT/libvirt/images** folder: * ws-2012-eval.iso - Windows installation ISO file. Must be renamed or simlinked. * virtio-win-0.1-52.iso - VirtIO drivers for Windows. Files that **MUST** be placed under **$BUILD_ROOT/share/files** are described in README file under **share/files** subfolder.1. Run **make build-root** to create directory structure. It will be built under '/opt/image-builder' folder, which is internally referred by **BUILD_ROOT** variable. 2. Copy prerequisite files to their folders. 3. Run **make test-build-files** to ensure that all files are in place. 4. Run **make** to show available image targets. 5. Run **make <image target>** to build image. 6. Image file should be saved under **$BUILD_ROOT/libvirt/images** folder.

commit_message:
Fix openstack server provider resource cleanup

* Pass the correct parameter to ResourceManager.delete (integer id, not
  resource object)
* Wrap each removal (os api and rally db) in individual try-catch, so
  that even if one resource has already been deleted (eg instance
  deleted manually) then all the other related resources (eg keypairs)
  will still be cleaned up.
* Expand fakes.FakeResource.
* Update tests

Change-Id: If9ce3d20493248779d0ea3708470847eee53dc72
Closes-Bug: #1277348

flake8 fixes for fuelweb_test

Added flake8 check to run_test.sh for CI checks
flake8 check ignores temporary files created when
running fuelweb_test.
Change-Id: I4bf99b63b1c690c0d86f0a20bc86fe9ecd9ccfb2
Closes-Bug: #1261547

subject: Don't hardcode environment.d
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-11 13:41:07.000000000', 'files': ['elements/dib-run-parts/bin/dib-run-parts'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/f760f11050c30c4350822a3d82e511dad108ff2b', 'message': 'Don't hardcode environment.d

Don't assume environment.d is always under /tmp/in_target.d. This makes
dib-run-parts more flexible, and less specific to diskimage-builder. For
instance, dib-run-parts is already used by os-refresh-config, but
/tmp/in_target.d/environment.d is never going to exist when it's called
by os-refresh-config.

This is useful b/c elements can now install os-refresh-config scripts
under /opt/stack/os-config-refresh/environment.d to influence how
further scripts are run. Specifically, the OpenSuse packages prepend the
OpenStack user accounts with "openstack-". Instead of checking for which
users exists with an if/else in all the os-refresh-config scripts that
need to do user related things, we can just update the scripts to use
$NOVA_USER, etc. The OpenSuse element can then install a file under
/opt/stack/os-config-refresh/environment.d to set NOVA_USER to
openstack-nova. We could have files that declare defaults as well within
each specific element, or just set a default variable at the top of each
os-refresh-config script.

Change-Id: Iadbfad995da657e2965fd55fc4ba3a88138b4cfc
'}]
commit_message:
Don't hardcode environment.d

Don't assume environment.d is always under /tmp/in_target.d. This makes
dib-run-parts more flexible, and less specific to diskimage-builder. For
instance, dib-run-parts is already used by os-refresh-config, but
/tmp/in_target.d/environment.d is never going to exist when it's called
by os-refresh-config.

This is useful b/c elements can now install os-refresh-config scripts
under /opt/stack/os-config-refresh/environment.d to influence how
further scripts are run. Specifically, the OpenSuse packages prepend the
OpenStack user accounts with "openstack-". Instead of checking for which
users exists with an if/else in all the os-refresh-config scripts that
need to do user related things, we can just update the scripts to use
$NOVA_USER, etc. The OpenSuse element can then install a file under
/opt/stack/os-config-refresh/environment.d to set NOVA_USER to
openstack-nova. We could have files that declare defaults as well within
each specific element, or just set a default variable at the top of each
os-refresh-config script.

Change-Id: Iadbfad995da657e2965fd55fc4ba3a88138b4cfc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/54/72654/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ENVIRONMENT_D_DIR=$target_dir/../environment.d if [ -d $ENVIRONMENT_D_DIR ] ; then for env_file in $ENVIRONMENT_D_DIR/* ; do
deleted_lines: if [ -d /tmp/in_target.d/environment.d ] ; then for env_file in /tmp/in_target.d/environment.d/* ; do

It's a quick fix. Usage of uuid to determine uniqueness of node will be considered.

Closes-Bug: #1271505

Change-Id: If9e8ac82ff9aa1c8359591821e70d4394a5a24ae
"}]
commit_message:
Check all node's MACs against MACs of all NICs of nodes

All MACs of node being added/updated are checked against MACs of all NICs of each existing node.
Tests are added.
It's a quick fix. Usage of uuid to determine uniqueness of node will be considered.

Closes-Bug: #1271505

Change-Id: If9e8ac82ff9aa1c8359591821e70d4394a5a24ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/00/72700/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #TODO(alekseyk) Simplify 'interfaces' and 'mac' manipulation logic meta_ifaces = 'interfaces' in metadata mac = kwargs.get('mac', self._generate_random_mac()) if default_metadata['interfaces']: default_metadata['interfaces'][0]['mac'] = mac if not metadata or not meta_ifaces: for iface in default_metadata['interfaces'][1:]: if 'mac' in iface: iface['mac'] = self._generate_random_mac()
deleted_lines: mac = self._generate_random_mac() if default_metadata['interfaces']: default_metadata['interfaces'][0]['mac'] = kwargs.get('mac', mac)

commit_message:
Fix for nailgun in setup.py

Packaged nailgun module is lowercase, however in setup.py its Nailgun
 this prevents being able to use 'python setup.py develop' which is needed
 for development envs

Closes-bug: #1272552

Change-Id: If255757012cf21542b6b0803d9fb30f757f915f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/45/70545/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Initial support of database migrations

syncdb command now uses alembic upgrade head

Added initial migration for Fuel 4.0

Implements: blueprint nailgun-db-migration

Change-Id: Ia340fa64b15e40fc2bb87125f746f5bf1b0530f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/91/67191/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # A generic, single database configuration. [alembic] # path to migration scripts script_location = alembic_migrations # template used to generate migration files # file_template = %%(rev)s_%%(slug)s # max length of characters to apply to the # "slug" field #truncate_slug_length = 40 # set to 'true' to run the environment during # the 'revision' command, regardless of autogenerate # revision_environment = false sqlalchemy.url = driver://user:pass@localhost/dbname # Logging configuration [loggers] keys = root,sqlalchemy,alembic [handlers] keys = console [formatters] keys = generic [logger_root] level = WARN handlers = console qualname = [logger_sqlalchemy] level = WARN handlers = qualname = sqlalchemy.engine [logger_alembic] level = INFO handlers = qualname = alembic [handler_console] class = StreamHandler args = (sys.stderr,) level = NOTSET formatter = generic [formatter_generic] format = %(levelname)-5.5s [%(name)s] %(message)s datefmt = %H:%M:%S

commit_message:
Initial support for single instance Cassandra Database

Reasons
- This code adds ability to create/delete instance
with mongodb service type. No other operations supported.
- Trove should support multiple extensions. One of the is NoSQL support.
Main goal is to add support for Apache Cassandra NoSQL database.

Changes
This code gives ability to create/delete instance
with cassandra datastire type. No other operations supported.

Change-Id: Ib48f6392765af49c2df1447c3df46675825d210f
Implements: blueprint cassandra-db-support

commit_message:
Add CRUD tests for telemetry alarming

Added API tests to list, create, get, delete alarms
using json interface.

Partially implements: blueprint add-basic-ceilometer-tests

Change-Id: I6c60c0fe55c7152d39d37077ffcc10e17aa6a620

commit_message:
Initial support for single instance Cassandra Database

Reasons
- this code adds ability to create/delete instance
with cassandra service type. No other operations supported.
- trove should support multiple extensions. One of the is NoSQL support.
Main goal is to add support for Apache Cassandra NoSQL database.
- Fedora images are not supported. There is no cassandra packages
for fedora.The _only_ one way to install cassandra on fedora
is to use tarballs archives.

Changes:
- this code adds ability to create/delete instance
with cassandra service type. No other operations supported;
- adding datastore/version registration for cassandra

Change-Id: I67733f0ba18aae513465d66bb48e44bbb316a575
Implements: blueprint cassandra-db-support

commit_message:
Fix API inconsistence when changing node's states

When the request to change the power state is accepted by the server
(HTTP 202) it shouldn't return any response message, just like the
request to change the provision state. In the future after WSME add
the support to edit the Header Location, we should include a link to
the /nodes/<uuid>/states subresource so that clients know how to
track the status of the request, there's a FIXME in the code
mentioning that already.

The patch also add a check to the provision_state tests to make sure
the response body has no content.

Change-Id: I4fb1cd5c226cee2f9e0977e83cf2ffa7786b3b4a
Closes-Bug: #1270160

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary json dumps/loads from tests

Tests used json dumps/loads to make sure each one will have a
separate copy of test data instead of pointer to original one.
Refactored this so now we have utility methods that return new
instance of test data each time.

Change-Id: I2306ba120fd61ede47e2762d910e004e66d6ce7f

commit_message:
Add node.states() to the client library

The node.states() does issue GET request at /nodes/<uuid>/states to get
the current states of that node.

Change-Id: I9e93447df53a0ba1e0f723e95af80fb126218626
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/79/70979/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NODE_STATES = {"last_error": None, "power_state": "power on", "provision_state": "active", "target_power_state": None, "target_provision_state": None} '/v1/nodes/%s/states' % NODE1['uuid']: { 'GET': ( {}, NODE_STATES, ), }, def test_node_states(self): states = self.mgr.states(NODE1['uuid']) expect = [ ('GET', '/v1/nodes/%s/states' % NODE1['uuid'], {}, None), ] self.assertEqual(expect, self.api.calls) expected_fields = ['last_error', 'power_state', 'provision_state', 'target_power_state', 'target_provision_state'] self.assertEqual(sorted(expected_fields), sorted(states.to_dict().keys()))

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-10 03:10:17.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient/commit/ee14e1ade373e5950d3cd9cf51e75381a2444c5d', 'message': 'Remove tox locale overrides

* tox.ini: The LANG, LANGUAGE and LC_ALL environment overrides were
introduced originally during the testr migration in an attempt to be

In actuality, this should be unnecessary and any place where it does

commit_message:
Remove tox locale overrides

* tox.ini: The LANG, LANGUAGE and LC_ALL environment overrides were
introduced originally during the testr migration in an attempt to be
conservative about the possibility that locale settings in the
calling environment could cause consistency problems for test runs.
In actuality, this should be unnecessary and any place where it does
cause issues ought to be considered an actual bug. Also, having
these in the configuration actively causes older pip to have
problems with non-ASCII content in some package metadata files under
Python 3, so drop it now.

Change-Id: Id761060cd974772749a82c42217647428e631324
Closes-Bug: #1277495

commit_message:
Fix Iterface misspelling from node-validate cmd

The result from a node-validate cmd includes a table with
'Iterface' as one of the headings. This changes it to 'Interface'.

Change-Id: Iac28d3c65f56ee6cd77f4611db0e513b1b9b008b

commit_message:
Fix baremetal stats type

As of 8a7b95dccdbe449d5235868781b30edebd34bacd the resource
tracker code is expecting stats to be a json string.  Baremetal
was setting it to a dict and it was breaking the db write.

Change-Id: I708fecd623c1a42d002c2b20bfdf06b625c9c287
Closes-Bug: #1279572

Tests remove useless config list cleanup code

With the change to correctly copy the config file list, tests
don't have to revert their changes to the list manually.

commit_message:
GlusterFS: Fix create/restore backup

Allow create_backup for GlusterFS volumes, but
only when snapshots do not exist.  (For now.)

Restore is a no-op for the driver, so allow it.

Related-Bug: 1247743
Closes-Bug: 1275977

Change-Id: I50b8f6cac684c967c7374bb43247a396ce936157

commit_message:
Large Ops scenario: ensure proper timeout validation

As the code checks that a server become active before moving to the
next one, the amount of time spent checking a server should be
subtracted from the global timeout.

Otherwise there will be a non negligible possibility that a server
would take a period longer than the specified timeout to boot.

Closes-Bug: #1250923

Change-Id: Ie4bfade4a2499c6ba318e83bd69fae3bf6a856bd

added_lines: def _call_until_true(func, duration, sleep_for): now = time.time() start = now timeout = now + duration while now < timeout: if func(): return True, now - start LOG.debug("Sleeping for %d seconds", sleep_for) time.sleep(sleep_for) now = time.time() return False, duration return _call_until_true(func, duration, sleep_for)[0] def call_until_true_or_raise(func, duration, sleep_for, error_message): """ Call the given function until it returns True (and return the elapsed time or until the specified duration (in seconds) elapses (and raise TimeoutException). :param func: A zero argument callable that returns True on success. :param duration: The number of seconds for which to attempt a successful call of the function. :param sleep_for: The number of seconds to sleep after an unsuccessful invocation of the function. """ result, elapsed_time = _call_until_true(func, duration, sleep_for) if result: return elapsed_time else: raise exceptions.TimeoutException(error_message)
deleted_lines: now = time.time() timeout = now + duration while now < timeout: if func(): return True LOG.debug("Sleeping for %d seconds", sleep_for) time.sleep(sleep_for) now = time.time() return False

commit_message:
This is a multi-commit patch for testing. Do not review

Process port_update notifications in the main agent loop
Improve handling of security group updates
Avoid re-wiring ports unnecessarily
Avoid processing ports which are not yet ready
Configure floating IPs addresses after NAT rules

Please do not review or score this patch. This is just a combination of
several commits for enabling parallel testing

Change-Id: I784a81e0b2a57a252fccc393e16ea69b9e1b04bb

commit_message:
Nicira plugin: Rollback changes when add_router_interface fails

Partial-Bug 1102301

If the implementation of the router interface in the NVP backend fails,
perform operations to rollback both Neutron DB and NVP changes.

Change-Id: I640a7d0057b356e718bc29af26cb68e9e703b236

commit_message:
Promote horizon.utils.memoized to Oslo

Makes the memoized decorator available for use in
other projects. The Memoized decorator from Horizon
makes use of the weakref support in Python to
automatically age out cache enteries. This makes
simple caching more manageable.

DocImpact
docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/sourcecode/horizon/horizon.utils.memoized.html
is now available to all projects

Change-Id: I9879611be143a1e6b13b9eb2fc972b9434727e54
blueprint: bp/promote-horizon-utils-memoized
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/87/71087/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2012 Nebula, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import functools import warnings import weakref class UnhashableKeyWarning(RuntimeWarning): """Raised when trying to memoize a function with an unhashable argument.""" def _try_weakref(arg, remove_callback): """Return a weak reference to arg if possible, or arg itself if not.""" try: arg = weakref.ref(arg, remove_callback) except TypeError: # Not all types can have a weakref. That includes strings # and floats and such, so just pass them through directly. pass return arg def _get_key(args, kwargs, remove_callback): """Calculate the cache key, using weak references where possible.""" # Use tuples, because lists are not hashable. weak_args = tuple(_try_weakref(arg, remove_callback) for arg in args) # Use a tuple of (key, values) pairs, because dict is not hashable. # Sort it, so that we don't depend on the order of keys. weak_kwargs = tuple(sorted( (key, _try_weakref(value, remove_callback)) for (key, value) in kwargs.iteritems())) return weak_args, weak_kwargs def memoized(func): """Decorator that caches function calls. Caches the decorated function's return value the first time it is called with the given arguments. If called later with the same arguments, the cached value is returned instead of calling the decorated function again. The cache uses weak references to the passed arguments, so it doesn't keep them alive in memory forever. """ # The dictionary in which all the data will be cached. This is a separate # instance for every decorated function, and it's stored in a closure of # the wrapped function. cache = {} @functools.wraps(func) def wrapped(*args, **kwargs): # We need to have defined key early, to be able to use it in the # remove() function, but we calculate the actual value of the key # later on, because we need the remove() function for that. key = None def remove(ref): """A callback to remove outdated items from cache.""" try: # The key here is from closure, and is calculated later. del cache[key] except KeyError: # Some other weak reference might have already removed that # key -- in that case we don't need to do anything. pass key = _get_key(args, kwargs, remove) try: # We want cache hit to be as fast as possible, and don't really # care much about the speed of a cache miss, because it will only # happen once and likely calls some external API, database, or # some other slow thing. That's why the hit is in straightforward # code, and the miss is in an exception. value = cache[key] except KeyError: value = cache[key] = func(*args, **kwargs) except TypeError: # The calculated key may be unhashable when an unhashable object, # such as a list, is passed as one of the arguments. In that case, # we can't cache anything and simply always call the decorated # function. warnings.warn( "The key %r is not hashable and cannot be memoized." % key, UnhashableKeyWarning, 2) value = func(*args, **kwargs) return value return wrapped # We can use @memoized for methods now too, because it uses weakref and so # it doesn't keep the instances in memory forever. We might want to separate # them in the future, however. memoized_method = memoized

commit_message:
Adds documentation for the Event API

This patch adds documentation for the Event API, and makes
some changes to the Event API so that sphinx can generate
documentation properly.

Change-Id: Ia1d4c471d528cbe9f6b6601e61630db99f16a3c6

commit_message:
Add option to disable Account ACLs

In addition to publishing the cluster supports 'account_acls' in the 'swift'
section of the info response.  This patch also enables cluster operators to
disable the storing and parsing of X-Account-Access-Control headers entirely.

Change-Id: I7d842080cb7bf9aba8401cddd860d569407def95

commit_message:
Add option to display deleted images

This changes needed for glanceclient
API v1: add 'deleted' filter to supported one
API v2: fix parsing error in 'deleted' filter

Change-Id: I81e26b47303d1408777bc0f006b04a4a4466ad2e
Closes-bug: #1026301
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/54/71354/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_index_with_deleted_filter(self): request = unit_test_utils.get_fake_request(is_admin=True) self.controller.delete(request, UUID1) output = self.controller.index(request, filters={'deleted': 'True'}) self.assertEqual(1, len(output['images'])) actual = set([image.image_id for image in output['images']]) expected = set([UUID1]) self.assertEqual(actual, expected)

commit_message:
Fix inconsistency in using the "enabled" field

The "enabled" field of project and domain entities should accept only
boolean values like the "enabled" field of user entity, so no more
integer values for this field because integers are not boolean values
in JSON.

Change-Id: I60476af77b02797d0b3991d414dd532c6542e48e
Closes-Bug: #1244423

commit_message:
Create task to persist volume information

Add task that persist volume information for manager/create_volume
flow. Remove this code from CreateVolumeFromSpecTask.

Before split CreateVolumeFromSpecTask on tasks dependent on how
volume should be created (from image, snapshot, source volume or raw)
common code should be moved to another tasks.

Partially implements: blueprint create-volume-flow

Change-Id: Ic51a3e9f359f71cffa6ded989210ebebc834f388
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/39/70939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default_provides = 'model_update' return model_update class PersistModelInformationTask(flow_utils.CinderTask): """Updates model of created volume with creation provided model and driver provided model. Provides updated volume ref. Reversion strategy: N/A """ default_provides = 'volume' def __init__(self, db, driver): super(PersistModelInformationTask, self).__init__(addons=[ACTION]) self.db = db self.driver = driver def execute(self, context, volume_ref, model_update): volume_id = volume_ref['id'] PersistModelInformationTask(db, driver),

commit_message:
Add task for volume driver initialization check

For manager/create_volume flow create a task to check volume driver
initialization. Remove this check from CreateVolumeFromSpecTask.

This change is a small step that will help to split
CreateVolumeFromSpecTask on tasks dependent on how volume should
be created (from image, snapshot, source volume or raw).

Partially implements: blueprint create-volume-flow

Change-Id: Iac83a231182a3c813972af4dd1a00f510141656c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/37/70937/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class CheckDriverInitializedTask(flow_utils.CinderTask): """Check if volume driver is initialized. Raises exception if not. Reversion strategy: N/A """ def __init__(self, driver): super(CheckDriverInitializedTask, self).__init__(addons=[ACTION]) self.driver = driver def execute(self): # we can't do anything if the driver didn't init if not self.driver.initialized: driver_name = self.driver.__class__.__name__ LOG.error(_("Unable to create volume. " "Volume driver %s not initialized") % driver_name) # Do not set error status for volume, it would be done during the # revert raise exception.DriverNotInitialized() CheckDriverInitializedTask(driver),
deleted_lines: # we can't do anything if the driver didn't init if not self.driver.initialized: driver_name = self.driver.__class__.__name__ LOG.error(_("Unable to create volume. " "Volume driver %s not initialized") % driver_name) # NOTE(flaper87): Set the error status before # raising any exception. self.db.volume_update(context, volume_id, dict(status='error')) raise exception.DriverNotInitialized()

commit_message:
Give an option to exclude volumes from snapshots in v3 api

All volumes will be backed by default if the instance is volume backed.
If the request has query param 'backup_only_root_volume' set to true,
only the root volume will be backed.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint exclude-cbs-in-snapshot
Change-Id: I0a256f63582a2559cea3911b0173af5a9dfec9b6

added_lines: root_volume_only = int(entity.get('root_volume_only', 0)) context, instance, image_meta, image_name, extra_properties=props, root_volume_only=int(root_volume_only))

Update docstrings to match guidelines

Per http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/,
one-line docstrings should end with a period and
be enclosed in """ instead of '''

commit_message:
Merge and rename generatedocbook/generatepot

The tool scripts used common functions, merge them to a single file
with different entry points.

Cleanup the merged file so that it passes the pep8 test.

Install the commands now as openstack-generate-docbook and
openstack-generate-pot. Leave a compatibility wrapper which should be
removed in version 0.8.

Change-Id: I7e4d651c4c62df58499e64e38528cb2cc4e9175b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/35/72135/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2011 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Local storage of variables using weak references""" import threading import weakref class WeakLocal(threading.local): def __getattribute__(self, attr): rval = super(WeakLocal, self).__getattribute__(attr) if rval: # NOTE(mikal): this bit is confusing. What is stored is a weak # reference, not the value itself. We therefore need to lookup # the weak reference and return the inner value here. rval = rval() return rval def __setattr__(self, attr, value): value = weakref.ref(value) return super(WeakLocal, self).__setattr__(attr, value) # NOTE(mikal): the name "store" should be deprecated in the future store = WeakLocal() # A "weak" store uses weak references and allows an object to fall out of scope # when it falls out of scope in the code that uses the thread local storage. A # "strong" store will hold a reference to the object so that it never falls out # of scope. weak_store = WeakLocal() strong_store = threading.local()

commit_message:
Ensure swift.source is set for DLO/SLO requests

SLO was setting it sometimes (the PUT path), but not others (the GET
path), and DLO just wasn't doing it at all. One could already
distinguish DLO/SLO internal requests by the user agent, but we should
set swift.source too.

Change-Id: I5d5b7dd49bd1522a9c830d0abd21fff92ae79a39

commit_message:
Move identity logic from controller to manager

The logic for changing a user's password will be used to implement
bp password-rotation.  Keeping the logic in the controller makes it
much harder to reuse.

Change-Id: I6e29a9f1875a3ea6dec4757db86c30497c0253cb

commit_message:
Changing testcase name to match our terminology

In design discussions we have been using the term 'self service' to
differentiate a user changing their own password and an admin changing
it for them.

Change-Id: Ibb19bb29e9330c381524209b7560e8c7e81a66be

commit_message:
Allow operators to customize max header size

HTTP messages max header line size has been increased from 8K to 16K
by default to allow using tokens including up to 14-15 catalog
entries.  The same issue
(https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1190149) may occur again in
the future, if keystone's catalog grows further.

Allowing operators to customize the max header size, will allow them
to have Cinder working whatever the size of the catalog (if the option
is properly set).

Change-Id: Iac269d96fadc96c1e9383dc03422f2d87196dd9d
Related-Bug: #1190149
DocImpact

commit_message:
Enforce current certificate retrieval behaviour

There appear to be no tests for retrieving certificates from the v2 api.

When you return a string from a webob request it inserts it as the body
in a standard WebOb Response. Because it returns a WebOb Response the
standard encoding behaviours in wsgi are not enforced and and all
responses are returned as straight text/html.

We can't change the behaviour of the certificate retrieval because it
will fail to be retrieved by auth_token middleware.

Change-Id: I8394f7ad2cc5a8f90b860170c2a5e3ecf334ac96
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/60/72260/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.tests import restclass CertSetupTestCase(rest.RestfulTestCase): def test_fetch_signing_cert(self): pki = openssl.ConfigurePKI(None, None) pki.run() # NOTE(jamielennox): Use request directly because certificate # requests don't have some of the normal information signing_resp = self.request(self.public_app, '/v2.0/certificates/signing', method='GET', expected_status=200) cacert_resp = self.request(self.public_app, '/v2.0/certificates/ca', method='GET', expected_status=200) with open(CONF.signing.certfile) as f: self.assertEqual(signing_resp.text, f.read()) with open(CONF.signing.ca_certs) as f: self.assertEqual(cacert_resp.text, f.read()) # NOTE(jamielennox): This is weird behaviour that we need to enforce. # It doesn't matter what you ask for it's always going to give text # with a text/html content_type. for path in ['/v2.0/certificates/signing', '/v2.0/certificates/ca']: for accept in [None, 'text/html', 'application/json', 'text/xml']: headers = {'Accept': accept} if accept else {} resp = self.request(self.public_app, path, method='GET', expected_status=200, headers=headers) self.assertEqual(resp.content_type, 'text/html') def test_failure(self): for path in ['/v2.0/certificates/signing', '/v2.0/certificates/ca']: self.request(self.public_app, path, method='GET', expected_status=500)

commit_message:
Use WebOb directly for locale testing

In the convert to Pecan we can't overload the Request type like we do
currently. At the moment we add only one method to request about
determining a locale which can be easily converted to a standalone
function.

Change-Id: I55de36d5ebc35ae868c9048dd4972df1634e2ee4
Blueprint: keystone-pecan

commit_message:
Fixes bug in exception message generation

When an invalid dogpile memcache backend was specified the resulting
ValueError message didn't contain the invalid backend properly.

This patch fixes the issue and adds a test to show the expected
behavior.

Change-Id: Ib9efee59e3839230034da95e48e47356c65b2fdb

commit_message:
Remove spurious tracebacks from tests

Some tests were deleting stacks in the background, thus provoking
tracebacks displayed later on during tests run. The patch waits for the
delete threads to prevent that.

Closes-Bug: #1278836
Closes-Bug: #1278937
Change-Id: I4b90eb6f90168803445039f9588a3052def6636a

commit_message:
Changes to cast variable as integer as XML API fails.

Code change to ensure that the type of the size variable is correct
when cinder is invoked through XML API. The extend volume code path
differs from volume create where the flow portion verifies that the
size variable is an integer; for extend the earliest place to cast
the size variable is in volume_actions.py.

Change-Id: Iaaed463f988769b8093604cd3b677b270dd2c5cd
Closes-bug: 1277233

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-10 23:38:51.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/common/openssl.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/2edfb664104f1384f1cbc49f6909bdddfc112086', 'message': 'Safe command handling for openssl

The openssl command line was passed to exec() as a string with
no attempt at escaping. This could lead to odd results if someone
configured their system with a space in the filename of a key.

Change-Id: I4faa2b66f79bf6ffddabf4a0f0b407ce9afa72d2
'}]
commit_message:
Safe command handling for openssl

The openssl command line was passed to exec() as a string with
no attempt at escaping. This could lead to odd results if someone
configured their system with a space in the filename of a key.

The fix is to pass the command to exec() safely, as a list.

Change-Id: I4faa2b66f79bf6ffddabf4a0f0b407ce9afa72d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/84/66084/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Delete rackspace database resource

Rackspace database resource 'Rackspace::Cloud::DBInstance' is not
required anymore and 'OS::Trove::Instance' should be used instead.

Closes-Bug: #1261870
Change-Id: I875048995792aa9993febf1391039d3a82ec849d

commit_message:
Provide region_name to trove-client

To create DBaaS instance in correct data center, need to provide
region_name to trove-client. This change updates clients.py in
contrib and passes region_name to trove-client.
Please note that, this is minimial change to fix rackspace Trove
resource and there is a blueprint(multi-region-support) to support
multiple regions.

Partial-Bug: #1261870
Change-Id: I8092b23923629e21b0ba9e487f64ce7f5c826015

commit_message:
Use passed filter dict param in core sql filtering

The existing code incorrectly ignored the passed in cumulative dict.
It functionaly got away with this error since the variable name
it used internally matched the one used in the scope of the caller
method.  Also, correct misspelling in the the same variable name.

Change-Id: Ib80df4dda2f1a8058a15d6407cae1532f4f988e4

commit_message:
Tests use setUp rather than init

Test classes should put their initialization code into setUp rather
than __init__. It gets called when the test starts.

Change-Id: Ice0631c864334435b895bad145f3b5b14dc3bffc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/34/69034/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def setUp(self): super(FederationExtension, self).setUp()

commit_message:
Update kvs assignment backend docs

The "key to data" mapping was not documented for the KVS
assignment backend.

Change-Id: Id3cf3e0d9b52ceae5099e6d3833cc88f7aa0f347
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/94/69994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """KVS Assignment backend. This backend uses the following mappings to store data: * Domains: * domain_list -> [domain_id, ...] * domain-{id} -> domain_ref * domain_name-{name} -> domain_ref * Projects: * tenant-{id} -> project_ref * tenant_name-{name} -> project_ref * Roles: * role_list -> [role_id, ...] * role-{id} -> role_ref * Role assignments: * metadata-{target}-{actor} -> {'roles': [{'id': role-id, ...}, ...]} Also uses: * Users: * user-{id} -> user_ref """ We enumerate the metadata entries and extract the targets, actors, and roles.
deleted_lines: def __init__(self): super(Assignment, self).__init__() The kvs backend stores role assignments as key-values: "metadata-{target}-{actor}", with the value being a role list i.e. "metadata-MyProjectID-MyUserID" [{'id': role1}, {'id': role2}] ...so we enumerate the list and extract the targets, actors and roles.

commit_message:
Do not use auth_info objects for accessing the API

Currently all the plugins in keystone.auth.plugins.external use the
auth_info object for acessing the identity and assignment APIs. This
change removes this and uses keystone.common.dependency instead.

Change-Id: I56f06a9c621b5127ae1ca786631c80207bb4286d

commit_message:
Notifications upon disable

Most entities have disable events that need to trigger other actions.
While disable is often a part of a update event, they are
semantically different events.

One alternative is to have the listener do a lookup, coupling it
tightly to the disabled entity. Sending a deliberate event is a
clearer indication of intention.

These notifications are internal only.

Change-Id: Ic0760ea715d9395bbf62ea90ea608ea85552fcbb

commit_message:
Remove vim header

We don't need vim modelines in each source file, it can be set in
user's vimrc.

Change-Id: Ic7a61430a0a320ce6b0c4518d9f5d988e35f8aae
Closes-Bug: #1229324

commit_message:
Remove vim header

We don't need vim modelines in each source file, it can be set in
user's vimrc.

Change-Id: Ie51ad62946afdf39eadcd59edaf8134ec10265c6
Closes-Bug: #1229324

commit_message:
make testing neutron api extensions optional

When the Neutron API extension that test case needs is unsupported
by Neutron plugin running, the test case will be skipped.

Change-Id: Ie3b0f94ea084076ccc10d6a141c9120bf9900395
Closes-Bug: #1270244

subject: Use message when creating Unauthorized exception
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-30 19:19:45.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/token/controllers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/b0a01de64ec1237d57337d0beba5793c40112c37', 'message': "Use message when creating Unauthorized exception

The Unauthorized exception was being created with an underlying
exception as its message instead of that underlying exception's message,
such that it can be translated.

Change-Id: I57a7729d2416dda8098da2ea67e867cad31ff83b
Partial-Bug: #1274638
"}]
commit_message:
Use message when creating Unauthorized exception

The Unauthorized exception was being created with an underlying
exception as its message instead of that underlying exception's message,
such that it can be translated.

Change-Id: I57a7729d2416dda8098da2ea67e867cad31ff83b
Partial-Bug: #1274638

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-04 20:58:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/d00736e7b18a26c7b2dfdaadb8971c6130001df3', 'message': 'Document priority level on Keystone notifications

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-02-06 04:04:53.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/event_notifications.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/a146bae2247560d50cc21462f22f215c0acb1cd7', 'message': 'Document priority level on Keystone notifications

commit_message:
Document priority level on Keystone notifications

In the notification docs, we never explicitly say that notification are
always set at the INFO level. This priority level is not configurable
by the end user through the keystone.conf and this change documents that
behavior in the event_notifications.rst docs.

Change-Id: I293db2b69a73a1b56fe0539e183ea13b87ce639a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/98/71098/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The ``priority`` of the notification being sent is not configurable through the Keystone configuration file. This value is defaulted to INFO for all notifications sent in Keystone's case.

commit_message:
Add missing isolated_cred cleanup to savanna tests

This commit adds a missing call to the tearDownClass in the base savanna
test class. Without this call every time the savanna tests run with
tenant isolation enabled the resources created will never be cleaned up.

Closes-Bug: #1275003

commit_message:
Doc - Keystone configuration - moving RBAC section

Moved the `Keystone API protection with RBAC` section between sections
`Configuration files` and `Adding Extensions`. It makes sense, since
it documents the `policy.json` file. This section was previously a
subsection of `Adding Users, Tenants, and Roles with
python-keystoneclient`.

Change-Id: I554f357c40666e67356e176ff82d057894e8bfe5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/84/71384/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _`API protection with RBAC`: Keystone API protection with Role Based Access Control (RBAC) ============================================================= Like most OpenStack projects, Keystone supports the protection of its APIs by defining policy rules based on an RBAC approach. These are stored in a JSON policy file, the name and location of which is set in the main Keystone configuration file. Each keystone v3 API has a line in the policy file which dictates what level of protection is applied to it, where each line is of the form: <api name>: <rule statement> or <match statement> where <rule statement> can be contain <rule statement> or <match statement> <match statement> is a set of identifiers that must match between the token provided by the caller of the API and the parameters or target entities of the API call in question. For example: "identity:create_user": [["role:admin", "domain_id:%(user.domain_id)s"]] indicates that to create a user you must have the admin role in your token and in addition the domain_id in your token (which implies this must be a domain scoped token) must match the domain_id in the user object you are trying to create. In other words, you must have the admin role on the domain in which you are creating the user, and the token you are using must be scoped to that domain. Each component of a match statement is of the form: <attribute from token>:<constant> or <attribute related to API call> The following attributes are available * Attributes from token: user_id, the domain_id or project_id depending on the scope, and the list of roles you have within that scope * Attributes related to API call: Any parameters that are passed into the API call are available, along with any filters specified in the query string. Attributes of objects passed can be refererenced using an object.attribute syntax (e.g. user.domain_id). The target objects of an API are also available using a target.object.attribute syntax. For instance: "identity:delete_user": [["role:admin", "domain_id:%(target.user.domain_id)s"]] would ensure that the user object that is being deleted is in the same domain as the token provided. List of object attributes: * role: * target.role.id * target.role.name * user: * target.user.default_project_id * target.user.description * target.user.domain_id * target.user.enabled * target.user.id * target.user.name * group: * target.group.description * target.group.domain_id * target.group.id * target.group.name * domain: * target.domain.enabled * target.domain.id * target.domain.name * project: * target.project.description * target.project.domain_id * target.project.enabled * target.project.id * target.project.name The default policy.json file supplied provides a somewhat basic example of API protection, and does not assume any particular use of domains. For multi-domain configuration installations where, for example, a cloud provider wishes to allow adminsistration of the contents of a domain to be delegated, it is recommended that the supplied policy.v3cloudsample.json is used as a basis for creating a suitable production policy file. This example policy file also shows the use of an admin_domain to allow a cloud provider to enable cloud adminstrators to have wider access across the APIs. A clean installation would need to perhaps start with the standard policy file, to allow creation of the admin_domain with the first users within it. The domain_id of the admin domain would then be obtained and could be pasted into a modifed version of policy.v3cloudsample.json which could then be enabled as the main policy file.

commit_message:
Require ctrl_location for encryption-type-create

This bug fix addresses bug #1267168, adding a default value to the
optional control_location parameter for the encryption-type-create
command. Prior to this fix, any invocation of encryption-type-create
that omitted the control_location parameter would fail. The failure
arose from the expectations of the cinder volume encryption type
API extension, which expects to always receive a value for the
control_location on encryption type creation.

control_location indicates which service will conduct the volume
encryption for the encryption-type under consideration; valid options
are 'front-end' (i.e., nova) and 'back-end' (i.e., cinder). The new
default value is 'front-end' and is used whenever control_location
is omitted from encryption-type-create invocation. For prior
discussion and information, see the abandoned patch below:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/58303/

blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes

commit_message:
Lowercase OVS sample config section headers

The "Sample Configurations" section of ovs_neutron_plugin.ini
has uppercased section headers.  In Havana the section headers
were normalized to lowercase, but the sample configs were never
updated.

Change-Id: Ic33392788317adcd6eb86caeef4f25aa4a3d10c8
Closes-Bug: #1279418

commit_message:
Reference dogpile.cache.memcached backend properly

It is dogpile.cache.memcached, not dogpile.cache.memcache
see
http://dogpilecache.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html?highlight=memcache#module-dogpile.cache.backends.memcached

Change-Id: Ia2aded1be82453b87a7734441537a5976385616e

commit_message:
Replace loguserdata.py by executing userdata as x-shellscript

This means losing the custom logging, but cloud-init logging seems
adequate for our needs. Especially since you can view the cloud-init
log from the nova console-log, meaning it is not even necessary
to ssh to the server.

Change-Id: I4fef02759bb1093d622404425aa9685de72d3a74

commit_message:
Replace part-handler.py with cloud-config write_files

This replaces a custom file writing mechanism with one that
already exists and gives full control over the files being written.

From a security point of view this replaces some delivered
executable code with some declaritive config, which should
reduce the attack surface.

Change-Id: Ic4072e93425a370e232355486d2302df2e693683
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/78/72478/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: #part-handler # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime import errno import os def list_types(): return(["text/x-cfninitdata"]) def handle_part(data, ctype, filename, payload): if ctype == "__begin__": try: os.makedirs('/var/lib/heat-cfntools', 0o700) except OSError as e: if e.errno != errno.EEXIST: raise return if ctype == "__end__": return with open('/var/log/part-handler.log', 'a') as log: timestamp = datetime.datetime.now() log.write('%s filename:%s, ctype:%s\n' % (timestamp, filename, ctype)) if ctype == 'text/x-cfninitdata': with open('/var/lib/heat-cfntools/%s' % filename, 'w') as f: f.write(payload) # TODO(sdake) hopefully temporary until users move to heat-cfntools-1.3 with open('/var/lib/cloud/data/%s' % filename, 'w') as f: f.write(payload)

commit_message:
Add ProphetStor DPL storage volume driver, Refresh code

Change-Id: Icf151fdb22ea89ac9a62f01a4147ba52392ab9c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/12/72312/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright (c) 2013 ProphetStor, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Implementation of the class of ProphetStor DPL storage adapter of Federator """ import base64 import httplib import json import math import errno import uuid import time import os from oslo.config import cfg from cinder import exception from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.volume import driver LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) dpl_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('dpl_pool', default='cinder', help='the DPL pool in which DPL volumes are stored'), cfg.IntOpt('dpl_iscsi_port', default=3260, help='the DPL iscsi tart port'), cfg.StrOpt('dpl_user', default=None, help='the DPL client name for accessing rbd volumes'), cfg.StrOpt('dpl_password', default=None, help='the DPL client password for accessing rbd volumes'), cfg.IntOpt('dpl_port', default=8357, help='the DPL port number'), cfg.StrOpt('dpl_server', default=None, help='the DPL storage server ip'), ] #FLAGS = cfg.CONF #FLAGS.register_opts(dpl_opts) DISCOVER_SERVER_TYPE = 'dpl' DPL_BLOCKSTOR = '/dpl_blockstor' DPL_SYSTEM = '/dpl_system' DPL_VER_V1 = 'v1' DPL_OBJ_POOL = 'dpl_pool' DPL_OBJ_DISK = 'dpl_disk' DPL_OBJ_VOLUME = 'dpl_volume' DPL_OBJ_VOLUMEGROUP = 'dpl_volgroup' DPL_OBJ_SNAPSHOT = 'cdmi_snapshots' DPL_OBJ_REPLICATION = 'cdmi_replication' DPL_OBJ_TARGET = 'dpl_target' DPL_OBJ_SYSTEM = 'dpl_system' GB2BYTES = 1024 * 1024 * 1024 class DPLCommand(object): """DPL command interface""" def __init__(self, ip, port, username, password): self.ip = ip self.port = port self.username = username self.password = password def send_cmd(self, method, url, params, expected_status): """Send command to DPL.""" connection = None retcode = 0 response = {} data = {} header = {'Content-Type': 'application/cdmi-container', 'Accept': 'application/cdmi-container', 'x-cdmi-specification-version': '1.0.2',} LOG.debug(_('Send command to DPL: %s %s %s'), method, url, params) # base64 encode the username and password auth = base64.encodestring('%s:%s' % (self.username, self.password)).replace('\n', '') header['Authorization'] = 'Basic %s' % auth if not params: payload = None else: try: payload = json.dumps(params, ensure_ascii=False) payload.encode('utf-8') except: LOG.error(_('JSON encode params error: %s'), str(params)) return errno.EINVAL, data dpl_busy = False for i in range(3): try: connection = httplib.HTTPSConnection(self.ip, self.port, timeout = 60) connection.request(method, url, payload, header) response = connection.getresponse() if response.status == httplib.SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE: dpl_busy = True break except IOError, ioerr: if ioerr.errno != errno.ETIMEDOUT or i == 2: LOG.error(_('Connect to DPL error: %s'), str(ioerr)) return errno.ENOTCONN, data except Exception, e: LOG.error(_('Connect to DPL failed: %s'), str(e)) return errno.EFAULT, data if dpl_busy: while True: try: connection = httplib.HTTPSConnection(self.ip, self.port, timeout = 60) connection.request(method, url, payload, header) response = connection.getresponse() if response.status != httplib.SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE: break time.sleep(1) except IOError, ioerr: if ioerr.errno != errno.ETIMEDOUT or i == 2: LOG.error(_('DPL Service Unavailable. Connect to DPL error: %s'), str(ioerr)) return errno.ENOTCONN, data except Exception, e: LOG.error(_('DPL Service Unavailable. Connect to DPL failed: %s'), str(e)) return errno.EFAULT, data if response.status not in expected_status: LOG.error(_('%s %s got unexpected response status: %s (expecting: %s)'), method, url, httplib.responses[response.status], expected_status) retcode = errno.EIO elif response.status is httplib.NOT_FOUND: ## in the case of querying a deleted volume retcode = errno.ENAVAIL elif response.status is httplib.ACCEPTED: ## set flag for polling event retcode = errno.EAGAIN try: data = response.read() data = json.loads(data) except (TypeError, ValueError), e: LOG.error(_('Call to json.loads() raised an exception: %s'), str(e)) retcode = errno.ENOEXEC except Exception, e: LOG.error(_('Read response raised an exception: %s'), str(e)) retcode = errno.ENOEXEC elif response.status in [ httplib.OK, httplib.CREATED ] and httplib.NO_CONTENT not in expected_status: # data is expected try: data = response.read() data = json.loads(data) except (TypeError, ValueError), e: LOG.error(_('Call to json.loads() raised an exception: %s'), str(e)) retcode = errno.ENOEXEC except Exception, e: LOG.error(_('Read response raised an exception: %s'), str(e)) retcode = errno.ENOEXEC connection.close() return retcode, data class DPLVolume(object): def __init__(self, dplServer, dplPort, dplUser, dplPassword): self.objCmd = DPLCommand(dplServer, dplPort, dplUser, dplPassword) def _execute(self, method, url, params, expected_status): if self.objCmd: return self.objCmd.send_cmd(method, url, params, expected_status) else: return -1, None def _gen_snapshot_url(self, vdevid, snapshotid): snapshot_url = '/%s/%s/%s' % (vdevid, DPL_OBJ_SNAPSHOT, snapshotid) return snapshot_url def getserverinfo(self): method = 'GET' url = '/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_SYSTEM) return self._execute(method, url, None, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED]) def createvdev(self, volumeID, volumeName, volumeDesc, poolID, volumeSize): method = 'PUT' metadata = {} params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, volumeID) metadata['display_name'] = volumeName metadata['display_description'] = volumeDesc metadata['pool_uuid'] = poolID metadata['total_capacity'] = volumeSize params['metadata'] = metadata return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.CREATED]) def extendvdev(self, volumeID, volumeName, volumeDesc, volumeSize): method = 'PUT' metadata = {} params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, volumeID) metadata['display_name'] = volumeName metadata['display_description'] = volumeDesc metadata['total_capacity'] = volumeSize params['metadata'] = metadata return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.CREATED]) def deletevdev(self, volumeID, force = False): method = 'DELETE' metadata = {} params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, volumeID) metadata['force'] = force params['metadata'] = metadata return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.NOT_FOUND, httplib.NO_CONTENT]) def createvdevfromsnapshot(self, vdevID, vdevDisplayName, vdevDesc, snapshotID, poolID): method = 'PUT' metadata = {} params = {} rqcopy = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, vdevID) metadata['snapshot_operation'] = 'copy' metadata['display_name'] = vdevDisplayName metadata['display_description']= vdevDesc metadata['pool_uuid'] = poolID metadata['properties'] = {} params['metadata'] = metadata params['copy'] = self._gen_snapshot_url(vdevID, snapshotID) return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.CREATED]) def getpool(self, poolid): method = 'GET' url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_POOL, poolid) return self._execute(method, url, None, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED]) def clonevdev(self, SourceVolumeID, NewVolumeID, poolID, volumeName, volumeDesc, volumeSize): method = 'PUT' params = {} metadata = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, NewVolumeID) metadata["snapshot_operation"] = "clone" metadata["display_name"] = volumeName metadata["display_description"] = volumeDesc metadata["pool_uuid"] = poolID metadata["total_capacity"] = volumeSize metadata["properties"] = {} params["metadata"] = metadata params["copy"] = SourceVolumeID return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.CREATED, httplib.ACCEPTED]) def getvdev(self, vdevid): method = 'GET' url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, vdevid) return self._execute(method, url, None, [httplib.OK]) def getvdevstatus(self, vdevid, eventid): method = 'GET' url = '/%s/%s/%s/?event_uuid=%s' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, vdevid, eventid) return self._execute(method, url, None, [httplib.OK, httplib.NOT_FOUND]) def assignvdev(self, vdevid, iqn, lunname, portal, lunid = 0): method = 'PUT' metadata = {} exports = {} params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, vdevid) metadata['export_operation'] = 'assign' exports['Network/iSCSI'] = {} target_info = {} #target_info['target_idetifier'] target_info['logical_unit_number'] = 0 target_info['logical_unit_name'] = lunname permissions = [] portals = [] portals.append(portal) permissions.append(iqn) target_info['permissions'] = permissions target_info['portals'] = portals exports['Network/iSCSI'] = target_info params['metadata'] = metadata params['exports'] = exports return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.CREATED]) def unassignvdev(self, vdevid, initiatorIqn, targetIqn = ''): method = 'PUT' metadata = {} exports = {} params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, vdevid) metadata['export_operation'] = 'unassign' params['metadata'] = metadata exports['Network/iSCSI'] = {} exports['Network/iSCSI']['target_identifier'] = targetIqn permissions = [] permissions.append(initiatorIqn) exports['Network/iSCSI']['permissions'] = permissions params['exports'] = exports return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.NO_CONTENT]) def createvdevsnapshot(self, volumeID, snapshotID, snapshotName = '', snapshotDes = ''): method = 'PUT' metadata = {} exports = {} params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, volumeID) metadata['display_name'] = snapshotName metadata['display_description'] = snapshotDes snapshotid = snapshotID params['metadata'] = metadata params['snapshot'] = snapshotid return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED]) def deletevdevsnapshot(self, volumeID, snapshotID): method = 'DELETE' url = '/%s/%s/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, volumeID, DPL_OBJ_SNAPSHOT, snapshotID) return self._execute(method, url, None, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED, httplib.NO_CONTENT, httplib.NOT_FOUND]) def rollbackvdev(self, vdevid, snapshotid): method = 'PUT' params = {} url = '/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_SNAPSHOT, vdevid) params['copy'] = self._gen_snapshot_url(vdevid, snapshotid) return self._execute(method, url, params, [httplib.OK, httplib.ACCEPTED]) def listvdevsnapshots(self, vdevid): method = 'GET' url = '/%s/%s/%s/%s/' % (DPL_VER_V1, DPL_OBJ_VOLUME, vdevid, DPL_OBJ_SNAPSHOT) return self._execute(method, url, None, [httplib.OK]) class DPLISCSIDriver(driver.ISCSIDriver): """class of dpl storage adapter""" def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(DPLISCSIDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) if self.configuration: self.configuration.append_config_values(dpl_opts) def _convert_size(self, size): size_name = ('B', 'KB', 'MB', 'GB', 'TB', 'PB', 'EB', 'ZB', 'YB') i = int(math.floor(math.log(size, 1024))) p = math.pow(1024, i) s = round(size / p, 2) if s > 0: return '%s %s' % (s, size_name[i]) else: return '0B' def _convert_size_GB(self, size): p = math.pow(1024, 3) s = round(size / p, 2) if s > 0: return s else: return 0 def _conver_uuid2hex(self, strID): return strID.replace('-', '') def _get_event_uuid(self, output): event_uuid="" if type(output) is not dict: return -1,event_uuid if output.get("metadata") and output["metadata"]: if output["metadata"].get("event_uuid") and output["metadata"]["event_uuid"]: event_uuid = output["metadata"]["event_uuid"] return 0, event_uuid LOG.debug(_('_get_event_uuid : no event received. default return.')) return -1, event_uuid def _wait_request_completed_with_event(self, volumeid, eventid): fExit = False status = {} status['state'] = 'error' while(1): try: ret, output = self.dpl.getvdevstatus(self._conver_uuid2hex(volumeid), self._conver_uuid2hex(eventid)) if ret == 0: if output['completionStatus'] == 'Complete': fExit = True status['state'] = 'available' elif output['completionStatus'] == 'Error': fExit = True status['state'] = 'error' elif ret == errno.ENAVAIL: ## in case of querying a deleted volume. status['state'] = 'available' except Exception as e: return { 'state' : 'error'} if fExit == True: break time.sleep(1) return status def create_export(self, context, volume): pass def ensure_export(self, context, volume): pass def remove_export(self, context, volume): pass # Cinder volume internal method def create_volume(self, volume): """Create a volume""" pool = self.configuration.dpl_pool ret, output = self.dpl.createvdev(self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id']), volume.get('display_name', ''), volume.get('display_description', ''), pool, int(volume['size']) * GB2BYTES) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: ## async process. res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(volume['id'], ret) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to create volume %s: %s' % (volume['id'], status)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='DPL failed to create volume %s:%s' % (volume['id'], ret)) else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to create volume (failed to get event) %s' % (volume['id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='failed to get event') elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to create volume %s: %s' % (volume['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='DPL failed to create volume %s:%s' % (volume['id'], ret)) else: pass def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, volume, snapshot): """Creates a volume from a snapshot.""" pool = self.configuration.dpl_pool ret, output = self.dpl.createvdevfromsnapshot(self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id']), volume.get('display_name', ''), volume.get('display_description', ''), self._conver_uuid2hex(snapshot['id']), pool) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: ## async process. res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(volume['id'], event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to create volume from snapshot %s: %s' % (snapshot['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="create volume from snapshot failed.") else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to create volume from snapshot (failed to get event) %s' % (snapshot['id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to get event") elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to create volume from snapshot %s: %s' % (snapshot['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="create volume from snapshot failed.") else: pass def create_cloned_volume(self, volume, src_vref): """Creates a clone of the specified volume.""" pool = self.configuration.dpl_pool ret, output = self.dpl.clonevdev(self._conver_uuid2hex(src_vref['id']), self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id']), pool, volume.get('display_name', ''), volume.get('display_description', ''), int(volume['size']) * GB2BYTES) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: ## async process. res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(volume['id'], event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to clone volume %s: %s' %(src_vref['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="DPL clone volume %s failed!" % self._conver_uuid2hex(src_vref['id']) ) else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to clone volume (failed to get event) %s' % (src_vref['id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data = "DPL internal server event error.") elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to clone volume %s: %s' %(src_vref['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data = "DPL internal error.") else: pass def delete_volume(self, volume): """Deletes a volume.""" ret, output = self.dpl.deletevdev(self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id'])) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) res = 0 if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(volume['id'], event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to delete volume %s: %s' % (volume['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='delete_volume unexpected error!') else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to delete volume (failed to get event)%s' % (volume['id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='delete_volume failed to get event') elif ret == errno.ENAVAIL: pass elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to delete volume %s: %s' % (volume['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='delete_volume failed') def create_snapshot(self, snapshot): """Creates a snapshot.""" ret, output = self.dpl.createvdevsnapshot(self._conver_uuid2hex(snapshot['volume_id']), self._conver_uuid2hex(snapshot['id']), snapshot.get('display_name', ''), snapshot.get('display_description','')) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(snapshot['volume_id'], event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to create snapshot for volume %s: %s' % (snapshot['volume_id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to create snapshot for volume %s" % snapshot['volume_id']) else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to create snapshot for volume (failed to get event) %s' % (snapshot['volume_id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to get event") elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to create snapshot for volume %s: %s' % (snapshot['volume_id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to create snapshot for volume %s" % snapshot['volume_id']) else: pass def delete_snapshot(self, snapshot): """Deletes a snapshot.""" ret, output = self.dpl.deletevdevsnapshot(self._conver_uuid2hex(snapshot['volume_id']), self._conver_uuid2hex(snapshot['id'])) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(snapshot['volume_id'], event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to delete snapshot %s: %s' % (snapshot['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=snapshot['volume_id']) else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to delete snapshot (failed to get event) %s' % (snapshot['id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to get event") elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to delete snapshot %s: %s' % (snapshot['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=snapshot['volume_id']) else: pass def create_export(self, context, volume): pass def ensure_export(self, context, volume): pass def remove_export(self, context, volume): """Removes an export for a volume.""" pass def initialize_connection(self, volume, connector): """Allow connection to connector and return connection info.""" properties = {} properties['target_lun'] = None properties['target_discovered'] = False properties['target_portal'] = '' properties['target_iqn'] = None properties['volume_id'] = volume['id'] dpl_server = self.configuration.dpl_server dpl_iscsi_port = self.configuration.dpl_iscsi_port ret, output = self.dpl.assignvdev(self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id']), connector['initiator'], volume['id'], '%s:%d' % (dpl_server, dpl_iscsi_port), 0) LOG.debug(_('return %d, output %s'), ret, output) if ret == 0: for tgInfo in output['exports']['Network/iSCSI']: for tgportal in tgInfo['portals']: properties['target_portal'] = tgportal break if properties['target_portal'] != '': properties['target_lun'] = tgInfo['logical_unit_number'] properties['target_iqn'] = tgInfo['target_identifier'] break if ret != 0 or properties['target_portal'] == '': raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='DPL failed to assign volume %s iqn %s' % (volume['id'], connector['initiator'])) return {'driver_volume_type': 'iscsi', 'data': properties} def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs): """Disallow connection from connector""" ret, output = self.dpl.unassignvdev(self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id']), connector['initiator']) if ret != 0: raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='DPL failed to unassign volume %s iqn %s' % (volume['id'], connector['initiator'])) def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): """Return the current state of the volume service. If 'refresh' is True, run the update first. """ data = {} totalSize = 0 availableSize = 0 ret, output = self.dpl.getpool(self.configuration.dpl_pool) if ret == 0: totalSize = int(output['metadata']['total_capacity']) availableSize = int(output['metadata']['available_capacity']) else: totalSize = 0 availableSize = 0 data['volume_backend_name'] = self.configuration.safe_get('volume_backend_name') data['vendor_name'] = 'ProphetStor' data['driver_version'] = '1.5' data['storage_protocol'] = 'iSCSI' data['total_capacity_gb'] = self._convert_size_GB(totalSize) data['free_capacity_gb'] = self._convert_size_GB(availableSize) data['reserved_percentage'] = 0 data['QoS_support'] = False LOG.debug(_('Current total size: %d, available size: %d'), totalSize, availableSize) return data def do_setup(self, context): """Any initialization the volume driver does while starting""" self.dpl = DPLVolume(self.configuration.dpl_server, self.configuration.dpl_port, self.configuration.dpl_user, self.configuration.dpl_password) self.context = context LOG.info(_('Activity DPL cinder volume driver')) def check_for_setup_error(self): """Check DPL can connect properly.""" pass def rollback_volume(self, volume, snapshot): """Rollback volume from snapshot""" ret, output = self.dpl.rollbackvdev(self._conver_uuid2hex(volume['id']), self._conver_uuid2hex(snapshot['id'])) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: ## async process. res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(volume['id'], event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to rollback volume %s: %s' % (volume['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='DPL failed to rollback a snapshot to volume.') else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to rollback volume (failed to get event) %s' % (volume['id'])) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to get event") elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to rollback volume %s: %s' % (volume['id'], ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data='DPL failed to rollback a snapshot to volume. error [%s]' % os.strerror(ret)) else: pass def _get_pool_info(self, poolid): """Query pool information""" ret, output = self.dpl.getpool(poolid) if ret == errno.EAGAIN: ## async process. res, event_uuid = self._get_event_uuid(output) if res == 0: status = self._wait_request_completed_with_event(poolid, event_uuid) if status['state'] == 'error': LOG.error('DPL failed to get pool info %s: %s' % (poolid, ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="DPL failed to query pool info.") else: pass else: LOG.error('DPL failed to get pool info (failed to get event)%s' % (poolid)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="failed to get event") elif ret != 0: LOG.error('DPL failed to get pool info %s: %s' % (poolid, ret)) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data="DPL failed to query pool info. Error [%s]" % (os.strerror(ret))) else: pass return ret, output

commit_message:
VMware: fix bug for exceptions thrown in _wait_for_task

If the _call_method fails, for example a resource is not found,
then the same call will be invoked again due to the fact that the
polling task was not stopped.

Closes-Bug: #1246848

Change-Id: If4818e41aed5be03395ab22afc0edf9abb3c34e1

Remove duplicate doc entry for swob

resulting in duplicate sections in the doc.

subject: Remove tox locale overrides
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-10 02:59:14.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/pbr/commit/ca67985ff37ce602d1892d958d0e7d48b2a6984a', 'message': 'Remove tox locale overrides

* tox.ini: The LANG, LANGUAGE and LC_ALL environment overrides were
introduced originally during the testr migration in an attempt to be
conservative about the possibility that locale settings in the
calling environment could cause consistency problems for test runs.
In actuality, this should be unnecessary and any place where it does
cause issues ought to be considered an actual bug. Also, having
these in the configuration actively causes older pip to have
problems with non-ASCII content in some package metadata files under
Python 3, so drop it now.

Change-Id: Ic09e1f7f90216064d550bc06c6301d5e1779b5aa
Closes-Bug: #1277495
'}]
commit_message:
Remove tox locale overrides

* tox.ini: The LANG, LANGUAGE and LC_ALL environment overrides were
introduced originally during the testr migration in an attempt to be
conservative about the possibility that locale settings in the
calling environment could cause consistency problems for test runs.
In actuality, this should be unnecessary and any place where it does
cause issues ought to be considered an actual bug. Also, having
these in the configuration actively causes older pip to have
problems with non-ASCII content in some package metadata files under
Python 3, so drop it now.

Change-Id: Ic09e1f7f90216064d550bc06c6301d5e1779b5aa
Closes-Bug: #1277495

commit_message:
Move create_, remove_ and ensure_export from drivers

create_export, remove_export, ensure_export are almost the same in
LVM and BlockDevice drivers. So they should be moved to
a common cinder.volume.iscsi module.

Change-Id: Id7aa0e10d6b346356312416aee179a1fe8bacef1

subject: Fix leaking DB details to API on error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-13 01:27:56.000000000', 'files': ['ironic/tests/api/test_nodes.py', 'ironic/common/exception.py', 'ironic/db/sqlalchemy/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/8ed876bc8ec9bd56ff9cbcd4bbfd378d4d8dff59', 'message': "Fix leaking DB details to API on error

Most of the DB exceptions contain DB details which aren't caught by the
traceback hook. The cleanest way to ensure the proper error codes and
messages are being sent is to catch the DBErrors and wrap them as
IronicExceptions. This patch will show the DB details if debug is enabled,
but hides them behind a generic message if debug is False.

Partial-Bug: #1272185
Change-Id: I3cc2549b8ffe1a1b642ecb7a10c7ae5a6975cc97
"}]
commit_message:
Fix leaking DB details to API on error

Most of the DB exceptions contain DB details which aren't caught by the
traceback hook. The cleanest way to ensure the proper error codes and
messages are being sent is to catch the DBErrors and wrap them as
IronicExceptions. This patch will show the DB details if debug is enabled,
but hides them behind a generic message if debug is False.

Partial-Bug: #1272185
Change-Id: I3cc2549b8ffe1a1b642ecb7a10c7ae5a6975cc97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/20/73120/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
add dstat to our list of statistics collectors

this will probably become the replacement for sysstat and pidstat
in the gate, but for now, just add it to the list, so we can start
getting data with it and make sure it's useful enough to drop the
others.

Change-Id: I9bb79cb0b5b0f9d98d03c31cddcda9a756aea54f

commit_message:
Define py27 assertFoo methods for py26

Frequent issue a test case is failing with py26,
because the used assert method like the assertGreaterEqual
is not defined.

Adding unittest2.TestCase to the base testclass when running
tempest with py26.

Change-Id: I5184fe88485b611c033e81f82177060460da7f1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/88/72388/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Ceph backup driver tidyup

Fixed typos and cleaned up log messages and docstrings.

Closes-Bug: 1276969
Change-Id: Idb1ba4f3315edb76fefc993b38b0590b4794345b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/90/71490/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adds migrate server extension for V3 API

Moves the migrate/live-migrate server functionality out of admin_actions into
its own extension. This part of the blueprint v3-admin-actions-split
allows more selective enablement of features contained in the admin
actions extension.

Note the XML api samples are no longer generated because
bp remove-v3-xml-api has been approved.

Refactor removes some exception handling for migrate along with the relevant tests
as those exceptions will never occur.

Partially implements bp v3-api-admin-actions-split
DocImpact: Adds os-migrate-server extension and moves migrate/live-migrate
functionality out of os-admin-actions into this new extension.

Change-Id: I6b29f501ad6bb9a6401b1c20cd419d9e05fe369b
